channel.title: Style - Digg
channel.description: Style on Digg: the best articles, videos, tweets, and original content that the web is talking about right now

item.title: Here's What Hogwarts Fashion Would Look Like In Every Era From The 1920s To 2020s
item.description: We petition this to be the official costumes of the Harry Potter movies.
item.kicker: HARRY POTTER AND THE DASHING HALLOWS

item.title: Acronym Brought The Jacket From 'Death Stranding' To Life
item.description: And it can be yours for $1,800.

item.title: Which Mask Should You Wear?
item.description: Here's a look at some of the types of masks you might encounter, how they work, what to consider when making your own and the level of protection they could provide.

item.title: The History Of The Hawaiian Shirt
item.description: From kitsch to cool, ride the waves of undulating popularity of a tropical fashion statement.

item.title: How The Ultra-Rich Are Doing Coronavirus Lockdown
item.description: Private jets, piano deliveries and underground shooting ranges: this is what life is like for the 1 percent in the age of coronavirus.

item.title: Here's A Handy How-To On Making 12 Different Fade Hair Styles
item.description: Barber Faheem Alexander demonstrates 12 different fades and his techniques.
item.kicker: GIRL I'M FADED BUT I FEEL ALRIGHT

item.title: Why Gore-Tex Is Still The Most Sought After Fabric For The Top Designers
item.description: What is it about Gore-Tex that makes entities like Supreme, Nike and NASA all want their products lined with it?
item.kicker: YOU LIKE SAYING GORE-TEX, DON'T YOU?

item.title: GQ's Stylish Friends Sent Us Their Big Fits From Home
item.description: From J. Balvin to JB Smoove, Lucas Hedges, Gunna, and beyond, we're still opening up our closets and giving it our best shot.

item.title: After The Pandemic, The Office Dress Code Should Never Come Back
item.description: Are "fancy" sweatpants here for good?

item.title: Why Is Every Influencer Wearing A Tie-Dye Sweatsuit In Quarantine?
item.description: All the cool kids on Instagram have figured out a way to make quarantine fashion, and why is literally everyone going live on Instagram right now?

item.title: Coronavirus Is Creating A Fast Fashion Nightmare
item.description: Dana Thomas, the author of the fast fashion deconstruction "Fashionopolis," explains the severe impact of coronavirus on Bangladesh's garment export industry.

item.title: Will I Ever Wear Pants Again?
item.description: After staying inside so long, sweatpants and leggings have become the new norm. How will this period of time effect the way we dress in the future? It's hard to know, but we took some time to hypothesize.

item.title: Jim Carrey Is Onto Something With His Quarantine Beard
item.description: Growing a beard is as much about coping through a crisis as it is changing your look.
item.kicker: GROW WHAT YOU NEED TO GROW TO COPE

item.title: No, Your Beard Is Not Actually Spreading Disease
item.description: If you look into the history of public health, you'll find instances where beards were blamed for the spread of disease. This is not actually true.

item.title: A Brief History Of The Acceptable High School T-Shirts Of The Late 1980s
item.description: Susan McCarty on the exploitation of conspicuous consumer desire.
item.kicker: WE'LL TAKE YOUR WORD FOR IT

item.title: 50 Works That Changed Our Critics' Lives
item.description: Our reviewers select standout moments in their field which still shape their love of the arts.

item.title: Homes Actually Need To Be Practical Now
item.description: One of the ironies of social distancing is that it can put privacy in short supply.

item.title: A Guide For The Perfect DIY Buzzcut, Isolation's Biggest Hair Trend
item.description: Hair getting shaggy in quarantine? Wondering if you could cut your own hair? Don't let coronavirus ruin your buzz(cut)! Take matters into your own hands and learn from a pro.

item.title: Isolation Is Changing How You Look
item.description: If you're stuck at home and feeling out of sorts, it might be time to experiment with a box of hair dye.

item.title: Shots From The Streets Of The Most Surreal, Sobering Fashion Season Ever
item.description: Yu Fujiwara captures the AW20 womenswear shows just weeks before the world locked down.

item.title: How To Win A Hair-Freezing Contest In Northern Canada
item.description: "Finally, I could have zero-gravity hair!"

item.title: The African-American Art Shaping The 21st Century
item.description: Kerry Washington on Beyoncé, Ta-Nehisi Coates on Kendrick Lamar, Oprah Winfrey on Toni Morrison, Issa Rae on "Scandal," and 31 other prominent black artists on the work that inspires them most.

item.title: How To Trim Bangs At Home Without Screwing Up
item.description: Wondering how to cut bangs and how to trim bangs at home without completely screwing up? Here, a hairstylist explains how to trim bangs in 8 easy steps, complete with pictures.

item.title: The Fascinating History Of Flokati, The Original Shag Rug
item.description: How the coziest carpets went from Alexander the Great's tents to your living room.

item.title: The Making Of Murphy's Bed: Urbanization And The Rise Of Fold-Down Furniture
item.description: William Murphy was not the first pioneer of space-saving furniture, but thanks to some clever innovation, good timing and fortuitous funding, his surname has become the household name in foldout beds and a widely used generic applied to similar designs.

item.title: It's All So… Premiocre
item.description: What do fake Eames chairs, extra legroom and $40 scented candles have in common?

item.title: Why Business Suits Are Going Out Of Style In American Offices
item.description: 50% of reported companies allow for casual wear in the office. Is the business suit going the way of the dinosaur?

item.title: High Ponies And Hairspray: Exploring The Beauty Rituals Of Cheerleaders
item.description: Photographer Hazel Gaskin shoots Goldsmiths Lions as they prep and perform on competition day.

item.title: How Coronavirus Face Masks Perpetuate Asian Racism
item.description: If you wear one here, you are gullible, selfish, foreign, sick and asking for attention. But in Asia, face masks mean something else altogether.

item.title: Dressing For The Surveillance Age
item.description: As cities become ever more packed with cameras that always see, public anonymity could disappear. Can stealth streetwear evade electronic eyes?

item.title: Meet The Designers Trying To Make Bernie Sanders Merch Cool
item.description: Fashion brands, Deadheads and even cactus purveyors are joining forces with a single mission in mind: make stylish Sanders T-shirts.

item.title: Here's How BMW Screwed Up Its Logo Redesign
item.description: As you may have heard, BMW updated its logo for the first time in over two decades, and, since it's a thing that happened in the world, some people are not happy about it.

item.title: We're In The Middle Of A Sports Bra Revolution
item.description: Technological advances and a growing line of research have paved the way for a new class of support systems that are comfortable, look good, and fit a wide(r) variety of bodies.

item.title: Dyeing For Fashion
item.description: By drawing on traditional dyeing techniques while utilizing the perks of modern technology, textiles designers are shaping a colorful new world.

item.title: How The NBA Tried To Stop Michael Jordan From Wearing Nike's 'Air Jordan 1'
item.description: "This will confirm and verify that the NBA's rules and procedures prohibited the wearing of certain red and black Nike basketball shoes by Chicago Bulls player Michael Jordan on or around October 18th, 1984."

item.title: Priests, Nuns And Rising Waters: Grand Delusion At Balenciaga
item.description: Fashion critic Cathy Horyn reviews the new and bizarre fall/winter 2020 collections as seen at Paris Fashion Week.

item.title: Intricate Patterns Hand-Carved Into Fruit And Vegetables By Takehiro Kishimoto
item.description: When he's not cooking them, Japanese chef and food artist Takehiro Kishimoto is turning fruits and vegetables into intricately carved sculptures too beautiful to eat.
item.kicker: ONLY HE'S ALLOWED TO PLAY WITH HIS FOOD

item.title: This Coronavirus Suit Protects You Inside A Literal Bubble
item.description: It's a hazmat suit for the urban commuter. And even though it's just a concept, it can't be realized soon enough.

item.title: Our Intersections Are Too Dangerous. Here's How To Fix Them
item.description: Engineers to advocates share advice for transforming your street corner.

item.title: The Definitive Ranking of Silicon Valley Shoes
item.description: Tech workers are, allegedly, the most boring dressers on earth, unless they're Jack Dorsey, in which case they occasionally look like high-fashion moon men.

item.title: A Grandmother Gatecrashes Fashion Week And Makes A Splash With The Help Of Two Cheeky Lads
item.description: She's now an up and coming global superstar ready to take on the world.

item.title: Why Supreme Is Happy to See Customers Burning Their Merch
item.description: It may look like a backlash against the super-exclusive streetwear brand, but it's pretty much the opposite.

item.title: The Invention Of The Bachelor Pad
item.description: And why are there still so few visions of comfortable, livable interiors for men?

item.title: Thank Syphilis For These Three Major Fashion Trends
item.description: What's the weirdest thing you learned this week? Your answer is about to get a lot weirder.

item.title: The Perma-Viral World Of The At-Home Nose Job
item.description: Nonsurgical cosmetic methods, like nose and face shapers, are all over social media as users chase the perfect selfie — but these rituals are nothing new.
item.kicker: DON'T GET BENT OUT OF SHAPE ABOUT IT

item.title: How Crunchy Technical Gear Took Over Fashion
item.description: From Merrell to North Face, functional gear has never been hotter.

item.title: 'You Haven't Given Up': How Prisoners Are Finding A Place For Personal Style On The Inside
item.description: In New York state prisons, a few accommodations for fashion have created a whole ecosystem of sartorial expression.

item.title: The Designer Ken Isaacs Wanted To Retool The Way We Live
item.description: A new book revisits the designer's visionary work, which advanced everything from flexible, "living" structures to micro-houses.

item.title: Foldable Phones Can't Catch A Break, Mainly Because They Keep Breaking
item.description: Will they ever be durable and cheap enough for most people?

item.title: Trademarking Color Is Absurd. But Not For The Reasons You Think
item.description: Companies like T-Mobile think trademarking a color helps steel their brand against competition. They're wrong.
